story:
Godlike Gaming is a comedy webseries about gaming, friendship and dreams. The show centers around a competitive 5 vs 5 game that requires tactics, teamwork and high mechanical skills. It is inspired by shows like Video Game High School, The Guild and Spaced as well as Edgar Wright’s other projects.

Sky is a MOBA (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena) player that dreams about being the best of the best, competing on the biggest stages and winning The World Championship in a big e-sport game. Her reality on the other hand is far from that. She lives in a shitty apartment, with an empty fridge and almost no income. Godlike Gaming is the name of her team and they can be annoying, frustrating and not focused enough on practice, but hey. It still beats solo que am I right?

The team are living their normal lives when they suddenly get into a local tournament, Battle of Legends. This would have been amazing if it wasn’t for the fact that one of their members dropped out. Not only will they have to find a new member, they also need to come together as a team and work with each other like never before if they are going to have a chance in their biggest shot of fame so far.

Sky

Sky is the main character of the show and is going to be played by Nicole Murray. The most important thing to Sky is the game and she is really good at it, but even though she is good her attitude is holding her back. Her sleeping schedule is not existing and she takes losses too hard. She also forgets to take the rest of the team into consideration and sometimes forgets that she needs to be a friend as well, not just a teammate. 

Sky wants to be able to influence everyone in the team since she has a hard time trusting them to make the right decisions and want to be able to do all the work if necessary. She’s also the one dreaming about the spotlight. These real life traits come out in the game in her role as the teams mid laner.

Fruit Cake

Will Maizel is playing Fruit Cake, the best friend of Sky. They have been friends since childhood. Sky can be a real mess and sometimes even unthoughtful, but Fruit Cake is always there for her. The team is her dream and Fruit Cake will be on her side doing what he can to support her. He is also the brother of the team's damage carrier, Pinkybr3ak, who can often get on everyone's nerves, especially Bash’s. Fruit Cake is doing what he can to try to keep them calm.

The best way to describe Fruit Cake is probably by his role in the team. He plays the support. He wants everyone to be seen and heard, don’t mind taking a step back to leave room for others, but will always step up to protect and support his friends.

Pinkbr3ak

The little brother of Fruit Cake will be brought to life by Omari Williams. The whole team might be nerds, but Pinkybr3ak is on another level. He reads every comic book, plays every game and knows all of the Star Wars lore. Pinkybreak easily clashes with people because he refuses to admit that he is wrong. You have to agree with him on things like who’s the best actor to play Batman or you are wrong and he will let you know how wrong you are.

Pinkybr3ak is the damage carrier of the team and he lives up to the stereotype. He thinks that everything revolves around him and if something goes wrong it’s never his fault.

Bash

Bash, played by Jamie Bautch, is the Tyler1 of the team. He is loud, cocky and gets easily angry. Because of his short temper Bash is constantly clashing with the “know it all” in the team, Pinkybr3ak. Bash’s heart is on the right side, but his competitive side hides it most of the time.

Bash is the top laner of the team. His attitude is “win lane, win game”. Simple as that. Don’t play around anyone else and trust no one. Bash is a very good mechanical player and he knows it, but he is a terrible team player. He doesn’t take orders well and thinks he can outplay more or less any one. 

Boxxxy

Last up we have Maddy Murphy as Boxxxy. Boxxxy is the new teammate of Godlike Gaming. She is very outgoing, sees the best in people and is usually very happy. Unfortunately what she has in empathy she lacks in brainpower. She speaks before she thinks and is always two steps behind everyone else in what is happening. To put it simple, she is rather stupid, but with a big heart.

Just like how Boxxxy wants to be there for everyone, but is stuck in her own world in real life, she also has the same role in the team as their jungler. 

Godlike Gaming is created by Eli Sundler. After rewatching VGHS and The Guild Eli wanted more scripted gaming series or movies, especially about e-sports, but couldn’t find anything. In a world where e-sport is as big as it is, we found it strange that we have almost no movies or shows about it. If you like basketball there is comedy, dramas. Live action, anime. Series, movies. The same thing goes with almost any sport, but not e-sport. That is why we are doing this show.

Eli

Eli, Daniel or Achmed (I go by many names). I’m the creator, writer, director and one of the producers for Godlike Gaming. I’m from Sweden but now live in LA where I’m a film worker by day and gamer by night. 

As a gamer I mainly play League of Legends, mains support (Thresh) and watch LCK (also watch other regions from time to time). Besides digital games I have spent a lot of time with board games and rpg. And as a filmmaker I have done several shorts which you can find a few of on my youtube-channel. Edgar Wright is my favorite director and I have taken a lot of inspiration from him while writing Godlike Gaming.

This show is about following your dreams and by doing this show I’m following mine. I have been dreaming about doing this show for five years and now it is finally happening. 

Josh

I’m Joshua Wallace, co-writer for GG. Texas-born, with a love of film but gaming whenever I get the chance I have worked in just about every crew aspect of student films, but have also previously done some writing and film work for a small advertising production company in Texas.

Put simply, this project is a combination of the things I love: filmmaking and gaming. Growing up on the Nintendo 64 and Gamecube, then graduating to PC gaming as a teenager, with many consoles in between, this project is right in my wheelhouse. From a writing perspective, I hope to help capture the joy of gaming and, more specifically, the ups and downs of a professional team and help bring such an interesting cast of characters to life. 

That said, I hope to see this project grow into its potential and become what we all know it can be.

Roy

Hey there! My name is Roy Shellef. I am from Tel Aviv - Israel currently living in Los Angeles and I am one of the producers of “Godlike Gaming”. I work as a producer - director for short films. Before this project, I produced two short thesis films: “catch 38”, who is currently in post production and “Hope” - a post apocalyptic film directed by Eli Sundler.

I produced and directed a music video: “Call Me Devil”  and a short film called “Thank You” who is an official selection for Miami Independent Film Festival - monthly edition.
Filming, directing and producing is a way of life but you can’t deny our gaming world. From Diablo 2 Lord of destruction, Crash Bandicoot, GOW, Ghost Of Tsushima and more… All these games inspired me to create stories and bring new ideas to our screens. 

This show is our way to bring you into our world and make you forget about life for a while or connect to your deepest and most hidden emotions.
Help us with this project and I promise you, you will not be disappointed!

Valeriia

My name is Valeriia Nikulina, from Russia. I’m a line-producer of Godlike Gaming. I graduated from the BFA and MFA programs in marketing. Since last year, I have been based in Los Angeles, where I am complete an MFA Producing program at the New York Film Academy.  While studying in the United States, I produced about 9 short films, some of which have received recognition at international film festivals. 

When I first read that script, I was really captivated by the story, because it is fresh and unique. I can’t say that I am a big fan of video games, but from a producer point of view I see a tremendous potential in that whole concept, because the video gaming industry is huge and shows no signs of slowing down.

Robin

Robin Landal here! I'm a musician, filmmaker, propmaker, larper, but not least- a gamer from Sweden! I've been working with Eli on their last films, mainly as sound designer and composer, but also as director of photography. When Eli told me about Godlike Gaming we were still shooting our first movie together, so now when the time has come to realize it I couldn't be more excited to join the production as the main composer!

I'm a child of the gaming era, just as so many others, and I know there are stories out there that has to be told. Just like sports, music, dancing, art or reading books, gaming can be both social and a way to find and get to know yourself. This is true for me, and I am still, at age 31, spending at average 2-3 hours a day gaming with my best friends as a way to relax and socialize.

Therese

My name is Therese and I live in Gothenburg, Sweden. I am a sound engineer and sound designer, and apart from concerts and theatre I have worked on many short films and tv productions. I love to give stories life by sounds! I have done the sound design for two of Eli’s short films, and we also both took part in creating an epic fire dance show for the opening act of a festival!

I am also a gamer since childhood, though mainly playing one player point and click puzzle games and strategy games.

Making a series is not cheap. Everything from location, crew, cast to permits, insurance and marketing cost money. Fortunately the first episode will be made as a thesis project and therefore comes with a lot of student discounts and already paid for equipment. Also a lot of free crew. That’s why making the first episode will be a lot cheaper than the rest. 

We ask for $6,000 for the first episode and for every $10,000 after that we will make one more episode. The hope is to make a six episode season (10-15 minutes per episode) to start with.

Eli has had big ambitions with previous projects, but low-budget and have therefore had to learn how to make professional movies with a minimal budget. With that said, a bigger budget can make the team go bigger with the show.

To put things in perspective: the first season of VGHS cost over $600,000 and Scott Pilgrim vs the World cost $60,000,000.

The best way to help is by pledging on this campaign here on Indiegogo. We have rewards for anyone that is pledging and every little bit counts. But we know that money can be tough and if even $1 is too much you can help by spreading the word. Tell all your gamer friends. Talk about us on your stream. Link to the campaign on your Instagram. Start a reddit thread. Every little thing helps. And if you want to do some sort of collaboration, it could be anything from a stream to just lending equipment send us an email.
story_txt:
Godlike Gaming is a comedy webseries about gaming, friendship and dreams. The show centers around a competitive 5 vs 5 game that requires tactics, teamwork and high mechanical skills. It is inspired by shows like Video Game High School, The Guild and Spaced as well as Edgar Wright’s other projects.
Sky is a MOBA (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena) player that dreams about being the best of the best, competing on the biggest stages and winning The World Championship in a big e-sport game. Her reality on the other hand is far from that. She lives in a shitty apartment, with an empty fridge and almost no income. Godlike Gaming is the name of her team and they can be annoying, frustrating and not focused enough on practice, but hey. It still beats solo que am I right?
The team are living their normal lives when they suddenly get into a local tournament, Battle of Legends. This would have been amazing if it wasn’t for the fact that one of their members dropped out. Not only will they have to find a new member, they also need to come together as a team and work with each other like never before if they are going to have a chance in their biggest shot of fame so far.


Sky

Sky is the main character of the show and is going to be played by Nicole Murray. The most important thing to Sky is the game and she is really good at it, but even though she is good her attitude is holding her back. Her sleeping schedule is not existing and she takes losses too hard. She also forgets to take the rest of the team into consideration and sometimes forgets that she needs to be a friend as well, not just a teammate. 
Sky wants to be able to influence everyone in the team since she has a hard time trusting them to make the right decisions and want to be able to do all the work if necessary. She’s also the one dreaming about the spotlight. These real life traits come out in the game in her role as the teams mid laner.
Fruit Cake

Will Maizel is playing Fruit Cake, the best friend of Sky. They have been friends since childhood. Sky can be a real mess and sometimes even unthoughtful, but Fruit Cake is always there for her. The team is her dream and Fruit Cake will be on her side doing what he can to support her. He is also the brother of the team's damage carrier, Pinkybr3ak, who can often get on everyone's nerves, especially Bash’s. Fruit Cake is doing what he can to try to keep them calm.
The best way to describe Fruit Cake is probably by his role in the team. He plays the support. He wants everyone to be seen and heard, don’t mind taking a step back to leave room for others, but will always step up to protect and support his friends.
Pinkbr3ak

The little brother of Fruit Cake will be brought to life by Omari Williams. The whole team might be nerds, but Pinkybr3ak is on another level. He reads every comic book, plays every game and knows all of the Star Wars lore. Pinkybreak easily clashes with people because he refuses to admit that he is wrong. You have to agree with him on things like who’s the best actor to play Batman or you are wrong and he will let you know how wrong you are.
Pinkybr3ak is the damage carrier of the team and he lives up to the stereotype. He thinks that everything revolves around him and if something goes wrong it’s never his fault.
Bash

Bash, played by Jamie Bautch, is the Tyler1 of the team. He is loud, cocky and gets easily angry. Because of his short temper Bash is constantly clashing with the “know it all” in the team, Pinkybr3ak. Bash’s heart is on the right side, but his competitive side hides it most of the time.
Bash is the top laner of the team. His attitude is “win lane, win game”. Simple as that. Don’t play around anyone else and trust no one. Bash is a very good mechanical player and he knows it, but he is a terrible team player. He doesn’t take orders well and thinks he can outplay more or less any one. 
Boxxxy

Last up we have Maddy Murphy as Boxxxy. Boxxxy is the new teammate of Godlike Gaming. She is very outgoing, sees the best in people and is usually very happy. Unfortunately what she has in empathy she lacks in brainpower. She speaks before she thinks and is always two steps behind everyone else in what is happening. To put it simple, she is rather stupid, but with a big heart.
Just like how Boxxxy wants to be there for everyone, but is stuck in her own world in real life, she also has the same role in the team as their jungler. 

Godlike Gaming is created by Eli Sundler. After rewatching VGHS and The Guild Eli wanted more scripted gaming series or movies, especially about e-sports, but couldn’t find anything. In a world where e-sport is as big as it is, we found it strange that we have almost no movies or shows about it. If you like basketball there is comedy, dramas. Live action, anime. Series, movies. The same thing goes with almost any sport, but not e-sport. That is why we are doing this show.
Eli

Eli, Daniel or Achmed (I go by many names). I’m the creator, writer, director and one of the producers for Godlike Gaming. I’m from Sweden but now live in LA where I’m a film worker by day and gamer by night. 
As a gamer I mainly play League of Legends, mains support (Thresh) and watch LCK (also watch other regions from time to time). Besides digital games I have spent a lot of time with board games and rpg. And as a filmmaker I have done several shorts which you can find a few of on my youtube-channel. Edgar Wright is my favorite director and I have taken a lot of inspiration from him while writing Godlike Gaming.
This show is about following your dreams and by doing this show I’m following mine. I have been dreaming about doing this show for five years and now it is finally happening. 
Josh

I’m Joshua Wallace, co-writer for GG. Texas-born, with a love of film but gaming whenever I get the chance I have worked in just about every crew aspect of student films, but have also previously done some writing and film work for a small advertising production company in Texas.
Put simply, this project is a combination of the things I love: filmmaking and gaming. Growing up on the Nintendo 64 and Gamecube, then graduating to PC gaming as a teenager, with many consoles in between, this project is right in my wheelhouse. From a writing perspective, I hope to help capture the joy of gaming and, more specifically, the ups and downs of a professional team and help bring such an interesting cast of characters to life. 
That said, I hope to see this project grow into its potential and become what we all know it can be.
Roy

Hey there! My name is Roy Shellef. I am from Tel Aviv - Israel currently living in Los Angeles and I am one of the producers of “Godlike Gaming”. I work as a producer - director for short films. Before this project, I produced two short thesis films: “catch 38”, who is currently in post production and “Hope” - a post apocalyptic film directed by Eli Sundler.
I produced and directed a music video: “Call Me Devil”  and a short film called “Thank You” who is an official selection for Miami Independent Film Festival - monthly edition.Filming, directing and producing is a way of life but you can’t deny our gaming world. From Diablo 2 Lord of destruction, Crash Bandicoot, GOW, Ghost Of Tsushima and more… All these games inspired me to create stories and bring new ideas to our screens. 
This show is our way to bring you into our world and make you forget about life for a while or connect to your deepest and most hidden emotions.Help us with this project and I promise you, you will not be disappointed!
Valeriia

My name is Valeriia Nikulina, from Russia. I’m a line-producer of Godlike Gaming. I graduated from the BFA and MFA programs in marketing. Since last year, I have been based in Los Angeles, where I am complete an MFA Producing program at the New York Film Academy.  While studying in the United States, I produced about 9 short films, some of which have received recognition at international film festivals. 
When I first read that script, I was really captivated by the story, because it is fresh and unique. I can’t say that I am a big fan of video games, but from a producer point of view I see a tremendous potential in that whole concept, because the video gaming industry is huge and shows no signs of slowing down.
Robin

Robin Landal here! I'm a musician, filmmaker, propmaker, larper, but not least- a gamer from Sweden! I've been working with Eli on their last films, mainly as sound designer and composer, but also as director of photography. When Eli told me about Godlike Gaming we were still shooting our first movie together, so now when the time has come to realize it I couldn't be more excited to join the production as the main composer!
I'm a child of the gaming era, just as so many others, and I know there are stories out there that has to be told. Just like sports, music, dancing, art or reading books, gaming can be both social and a way to find and get to know yourself. This is true for me, and I am still, at age 31, spending at average 2-3 hours a day gaming with my best friends as a way to relax and socialize.
Therese

My name is Therese and I live in Gothenburg, Sweden. I am a sound engineer and sound designer, and apart from concerts and theatre I have worked on many short films and tv productions. I love to give stories life by sounds! I have done the sound design for two of Eli’s short films, and we also both took part in creating an epic fire dance show for the opening act of a festival!
I am also a gamer since childhood, though mainly playing one player point and click puzzle games and strategy games.


Making a series is not cheap. Everything from location, crew, cast to permits, insurance and marketing cost money. Fortunately the first episode will be made as a thesis project and therefore comes with a lot of student discounts and already paid for equipment. Also a lot of free crew. That’s why making the first episode will be a lot cheaper than the rest. 
We ask for $6,000 for the first episode and for every $10,000 after that we will make one more episode. The hope is to make a six episode season (10-15 minutes per episode) to start with.
Eli has had big ambitions with previous projects, but low-budget and have therefore had to learn how to make professional movies with a minimal budget. With that said, a bigger budget can make the team go bigger with the show.
To put things in perspective: the first season of VGHS cost over $600,000 and Scott Pilgrim vs the World cost $60,000,000.


The best way to help is by pledging on this campaign here on Indiegogo. We have rewards for anyone that is pledging and every little bit counts. But we know that money can be tough and if even $1 is too much you can help by spreading the word. Tell all your gamer friends. Talk about us on your stream. Link to the campaign on your Instagram. Start a reddit thread. Every little thing helps. And if you want to do some sort of collaboration, it could be anything from a stream to just lending equipment send us an email.

story:
Logline: Carlo & Tia explore independent restaurants in a city showcasing the connection between the food, the culture, and the community. Each ten-minute episode will focus on an individual restaurant and neighborhood, and each season will take place in a specific city.

 

Summary: The Eats is food docu-web series that combines the fast-paced elements of a short form YouTube food vlog and the quality of a long form traditional food television show. The series follows two Chicago-based foodies Carlo and Tia. Carlo is personal trainer and Yelp Elite food reviewer. Tia is social media and branding specialist. Oh, and they are one of the cutest couples you’ll ever see!

In each season of The Eats Carlo and Tia will explore different restaurants in and around a particular city—with the first two seasons starting off in Chicago. They will not only highlight the food, but the restaurant and the community. The Eats focuses on the stories of the restaurants and how those stories impact the menu and the community.

Background: Aaron Potts first came up with the idea for The Eats in the summer of 2018. Aaron was working in a restaurant in Chicago as food runner and became intrigued by the detail and care the restaurant’s leadership paid to the menu and how the connection the local community had to the restaurant. He realized the community felt connected to the restaurant not only because of the quality of the food, but because of the restaurant’s story and its relationship with the neighborhood; he discovered that the ethos of the restaurant and the quality of the food were inextricably connected.

Social Impact: The Eats works to raise the awareness and prestige of local restaurants and business, and to draw attention to the communities they serve. The hope is that through highlighting these local businesses that individuals and organizations will be encouraged to invest more in these neighborhoods.

story:
That Monster Show is an Adult-Swim-Style animated TV show pilot. 

Fans of Nightmare Before Christmas, Beetlejuice, and Haunted Mansion are sure to treasure this comedic, otherworldly adventure.

It recounts the mythical tale of FIVE MONSTERS from another dimension, who are banished to their version of Hell: FLORIDA!

Can they use their dark magic to construct a machine, that will re-open the portal, and return them to their home world?

Florida can be a dangerous place for anyone -- but a land of sunshine, golf courses, and beaches is the last place our Monsters want to be.

While we are here, let’s have a look at these MONSTERS, shall we?

Their leader, an alcoholic Vampire Queen (look like she’s ready for some rumpy pumpy!)

a hipster outdoorsman Werewolf

a hypochondriac scientist that is frankensteining HIMSELF

a sad Ghost Girl

and a murderous mutant child (well that just takes the biscuit!)

There, they struggle against their adversary, the charismatic Pastor Bruce Godmanson -- An aspiring cult leader who rallies a HOLY MILITIA of old people and rednecks to destroy them.

And you can surely expect some appearances by yours truly, Professor Sylvanus Huxley -- adventurer, occult historian, -- and occasional late night TV host. 

These marvelous characters are voiced by the talented Joanie Brosas, LeeAnna Vamp, Dan Foster, Cole Johnson, and more to be announced in due time. 

And it's all written and directed by Carl King and animated by Lance Myers, the team that brought you The Oracle of Outer Space.

My, you’ve listened to this old Crusty Dragon for long enough. Do be a good chap, and help us by supporting That Monster Show, won't you?

story:
Who we are!

Aloha! We are Geri and Cyndi, the creators of The Peek-a-Bows; a children's musical entertainment group. The Peek-a-Bows are a local staple in Maui, Hawaiʻi and we've been performing, entertaining, and educating keiki (kids) for over 11 years!

And now we are so excited to announce that we are taking The Peek-a-Bows to the next level. We are currently in full production on 3 episodes of The Peek-a-Bows Series which is focused on supporting early childhood development. Our show mixes music, animation, Hawaiian values education and also promotes joy and well-being! 

We are best friends that met 18 years ago while performing in the Nā Hōkū Hanohano award-winning production ʻUlalena in Lāhainā, Maui.  We have been professional entertainers since childhood and this is truly our passion. We both grew up in musical families and have always been involved in some form of the arts. You may have seen Geri as the host of the OC16 show Self-Made in Hawaiʻi, as a Miss Aloha Hula contestant, or as a vocalist and aerial acrobat at ʻUlalena. You may also recognize Cyndi on AIG commercials, impersonating Janet Jackson in Waikīkī, or recognize her as the voice of ʻUlalena.  Or you may have even flown as passengers on one of our flights working together as flight attendants for a Hawaiʻi-based airline.

       

Bringing joy and music to children is our hope.  We have a great team of incredible individuals that are helping us shape The Peek-a-Bows Series to be the best it could be. We have been working closely with Hawaiian cultural advisors, professional animators, educational specialists, musicians, actors, and music producers.

Who are The Peek-a-Bows?

The Peek-a-Bows are three colorful sisters, ʻAlani, Lena, and Poni.  They live in Ke Ānuenue, the rainbow, and slide down the rainbow anytime the children of Hawaiʻi need assistance to work through any situation. Joining the Bows on their adventures are their animal friends ​Uncle Huli the Kāhuli Snail, Maka the Hāʻukeʻuke Sea Urchin, and Welo the Pueo.

 

We need you!

Our goal is to create music and animated/live-action episodes consisting of musical and educational, culturally-based content for young children that supports early childhood education. This includes original songs written by us, Hawaiian words of the day, cultural values, and a lesson taught within each episode's theme.

We are so grateful to have recently received a grant from the County of Mauiʻs Office of Economic Development. Now, we need your help to complete our project to the best quality possible. 

Our music album will be an EP (“extended play”) or mini-album consisting of 5 original songs that will be available for digital download and streaming on all music platforms. Our mini-series will be offered online through streaming sites and also available for digital download.

 

Your donation also helps a local non-profit!

We are so thankful for the support we have and continue to receive from Lokahi Pacific, our fiscal sponsor. Through this partnership, your pledge is helping a Maui non-profit that aims to support our local community.  Your donation is also tax-deductible (whoop, whoop)!

We hope to raise funds within the next thirty days to go towards: 

1. Completing our EP album of original songs 

2. Completing our 3-episode mini-series

3. Marketing via social media and various medium

Our goal is to raise $25,000 to be used towards the production and promotion expenses. Other related expenses include paying for musicians, singers, performers, equipment rental, film crew, and administrative operations. 

 

You get early-bird access to our merchandise!

Become a “Backer” and you could receive logo wear not yet available to the public. Our rewards range from logo wear, get behind the scenes updates, social media shoutouts, a video call from The Peek-a-Bows, or, your child could appear in an episode! 

Thank you!

If we don't reach our entire goal, ʻaʻole pilikia (no problem!) We are thankful for any contributions made.  If we don't reach our funding goal, our project will still go on, however, adjustments will be made wherever necessary.  

 

Our History!

The Peek-a-Bows originated as “The Fairies”  in 2008 when we were asked by a close friend and fellow ʻUlalena cast member to perform a 30-minute sing-a-long show for her daughter’s 1-year-old Baby lūʻau. We quickly began receiving lots of requests to perform for other baby parties on Maui, so we decided to pursue this performance group further as a new venture. We changed our name to “The Babydolls” and began entertaining children as different characters for themed parties.

Our name changed once more to “The Peek-a-Bows” when our group transformed into a television pilot.  We filmed the pilot at Maui Community College (now the University of Hawaii, Maui College) with the help of their Media Department and our talented friends. Fast forward 11 years later and with the advancement of technology, we felt it was the right time to bring the Bows to life as animated characters.

 

Challenges

Circumstances due to COVID-19 restrictions have allowed us to be more creative in how we execute this project. Filming large groups and social distancing has proved to be challenging while trying to film live-action scenes, however, we continue to follow the guidelines and rules set by the County of Maui and find ways to make it work.

 

Other Ways You Can Help!

No worries if you arenʻt able to be a backer. We are happy to have you here either way.  We would appreciate it if you could share our campaign with others and please ‘subscribe’ to our email mailing list at www.thepeekabows.com to stay updated on our journey, music, and episode releases!  Please visit our website for additional information and we look forward to sharing our final mini-series with you. 

Mahalo!!

story:
"What is Homegrown?"

Homegrown teaches self love through mindful movement and play.      Our creative team has 30 years collective experience as professional arts educators, producers, and performing artists.

After providing 250 live, virtual, dance a long adventures over zoom this past year, Homegrown was able to connect kids across the United States and Canada. Our goal is to to give our friends around the world a space to move, play, and create while developing self love and self trust. 

Your contribution will not only fund the production of Homegrown Season One; bringing mindful movement, imagination, and play into homes around the world, your contribution will also propel the message of healthy mind+body connection for our future leaders.

 

"Where is the money going?"

We need $20,000 to produce our pilot season, and that's being extremely frugal and resourceful. Fortunately, we have an amazing team who understands that limitation is an opportunity for innovation. 

Here's the breakdown of our budget and how we plan to use your contribution:

Creative Team 

  • Actors
  • Puppeteer 
  • Writers
  • Set Design
  • Film Crew
  • Sound Technician
  • Lighting Technician 
  • Post Production
  • Editors
  • Marketing

Technical

  • Lighting equipment
  • Film Equipment
  • Sound equipment

Production

  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Set Construction
  • Hair/Make Up

 

"Let's talk PERKS!"

Even though we're making a kids show, the PERKS are for everyone!      We are a group of amazing arts educators and entertainers, and our perks showcase our collective expertise.

Discounted virtual vocal lessons to unleash your inner Karaoke Queen, 30 day Sweat Challenge to amp up your fitness goals, even a bonified STONKEY DONKEY shout out to your favorite friend, there are PERKS for everyone who would love to support.

Keeping with our mission of mindful movement and play, our group PERKS are a great way to connect to yourself, and others. Homegrown Virtual Birthday Adventure, Moms Night In (BYO) Dance Party, or a Homegrown for Grown Ups master class are all lead by Rebekah, and are all amazing options.

 

Homegrown; Stories that MOVE you.

“I love myself. I trust myself. I love being me!”

We begin and end every Homegrown mindful movement class with these simple, but profound, words. Forward thinking parents around the globe now understand the power of play as an indisputable tool for their child's growth. 

Art is no longer an extracurricular, but an integral part of childhood development. 

Homegrown encourages a healthy friendship between the mind and the body through dynamic movement training, imaginative play and captivating storytelling. Our virtual adventures include Ballet, Musical Theatre, Comedy Improv, Capoeira, and Yoga techniques. 

Join the MOVEMENT! 

Homegrown isn’t about learning and repeating dance steps, it’s about discovering what moves us in the first place. We create a safe space to embody your childs inner Hero, Warrior, Clown, or Rain Cloud. We celebrate all expressions of self, because the human experience is vast.

Our live, virtual classes will continue Fall 2021.

Homegrown Reach! 

In only 7 months, Homegrown reached young learners across VA, WV, PA, NY, GA, TX, CO, CA, Alaska, and Canada. Homegrown has a 98% retention rate; almost 100% of friends who try a Homegrown class, continue to learn with us. It's that effective! It's that fun! 

 

"Tell me about the challenges."

Homegrown launched September of 2020, during the Covid-19 pandemic; one of the darkest times in recent history. Founder, Rebekah Rickards, saw an immediate and urgent need for children who were isolated during quarantine to move, play, and feel connected to others- but maybe most importantly; feel connected to themselves.

A movement that came about from a great need during global chaos, now emerges like a welcomed rainbow after a storm. We are here to stay. 

 

"I can't contribute, but can I still help?"

Your support means the world to us! If you can't contribute, we ask that you follow us on social media (IG/FB: home757grown), and help us spread the word!

Sharing this Indiegogo campaign to 2-3 of your friends or colleagues could make a huge impact in helping us reach our goal!
story_txt:
"What is Homegrown?"
Homegrown teaches self love through mindful movement and play.      Our creative team has 30 years collective experience as professional arts educators, producers, and performing artists.
After providing 250 live, virtual, dance a long adventures over zoom this past year, Homegrown was able to connect kids across the United States and Canada. Our goal is to to give our friends around the world a space to move, play, and create while developing self love and self trust. 
Your contribution will not only fund the production of Homegrown Season One; bringing mindful movement, imagination, and play into homes around the world, your contribution will also propel the message of healthy mind+body connection for our future leaders.

 
"Where is the money going?"
We need $20,000 to produce our pilot season, and that's being extremely frugal and resourceful. Fortunately, we have an amazing team who understands that limitation is an opportunity for innovation. 
Here's the breakdown of our budget and how we plan to use your contribution:
Creative Team 

Actors
Puppeteer 
Writers
Set Design
Film Crew
Sound Technician
Lighting Technician 
Post Production
Editors
Marketing

Technical

Lighting equipment
Film Equipment
Sound equipment

Production

Props
Costumes
Set Construction
Hair/Make Up

story:
My name is David Mayne and I'm the creator and host of Happy Hour History.

I've been a filmmaker for over three decades and I passionately believe in the power of film/video to make the world a smarter, funnier and better place.

As a happy accident, (while imbibing of course) I discovered the amazing connections between booze and major events in human history, finding scores of captivating stories to tell.

But, if you’re like me, you find most history documentaries to be a bit dry and sleepy. So I combined my background of working on documentaries, commercials and independent films to mix the perfect cocktail of a web series that entertains, while it educates.

Together we will explore the roots behind familiar classic cocktails, like the Moscow Mule and the Side Car and learn how they are connected to two catastrophic world wars. We’ll learn how rum played a pivotal role in the American Revolution and how the Bees Knees and the Scofflaw helped frame not only the Prohibition Era – but also the early Women’s Rights Movement. Going further back in time we’ll learn about the evolution of Scotch Whiskey and why we now have safe water to drink from our faucets.

I’ve partnered with a team of experts that include award-winning animators, cinematographers, audio engineers and skilled crew members based in Portland, Oregon, a handful of accomplished historians, and bartenders span the entire US.

We are so passionate about this series, we’ve already produced our pilot episode with zero budget (through many favors asked and drinks bought). 

Watch the Pilot Episode here.

We've also done significant work on 5 more episodes for the first season with scripts and treatments are written. Production is ready to go and PBS Digital is very interested in distributing the series. Can’t wait to start the season fully-funded!

We love the idea that through Indiegogo our audience is our executive producer. You will give us the support and creative freedom to create a history series like no other.

Your support will fund the production of Happy Hour History - Season 1. We’ve set our initial funding goal for 3 brand new episodes while doing some touch up work on the pilot episode. Then if you help us reach our stretch goal (pretty please) we’ll be able to produce two more episodes for a total of 6!

We have a production staff of director, producer, historians, cinematographers, sound, make up/wardrobe, animators, audio engineers (let us not forget) bartenders who have all committed to work on the project at lower fees because they believe in the work. Here’s the breakdown for creating one episode.

We look forward to building a community around Happy Hour History providing screenings and special happy hours around the USA. We are interested in hearing your ideas and creating the stories you’d like to see in future episodes.

We’ll begin shooting on episodes starting in March 2018, and will immediately start post-production with the goal of releasing an episode once per month.

We are small, independently-funded yet determined to create this series. Creating high-quality documentary content is expensive – but our team is uniquely experienced with delivering great history-content on a limit budget.

However, working under-budget reduces our access to licensing quality archival imagery, limits the number of animations we can create and reduces the ability to travel to bars (where our stellar bartenders work) or unique historical sites throughout the country.

If we don’t reach our goal, we’ll stretch the funds and seek traditional funding from spirits brands although that may limit our creative freedom. 

SPREAD THE NEWS --- Share, share and share some more!

Tell your friends and wealthy relatives! Indiegogo has some great, easy sharing tools located at the top of the page.

Thank you so much. You’re the Bee’s Knees!

story:
WOW ... THANK YOU!!

We did it! Thanks to your support we will be able to finish our first season of Tangible Hope Project and start planning for Season 2!

If you missed out on being part of our People Powered Campaign here on Indiegogo you can become a supporter of Tangible Hope Project by making a tax-deductible donation through our website: www.tangiblehopeproject.org.  

Please *subscribe* to our YouTube channel to see all the latest episodes and follow along as Hope continues to spread across America.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

 

Because of the AMAZING support of our community, in just 10 days, we were able to reach our initial goal of $10,000 to finish Season 1! NOW we are s t r e t c h i n g the goal of our Indiegogo campaign to $15,000 ... all additional funds raised will go to pre-production costs  for SEASON 2!! 

 

Tangible Hope Project is an award-winning 10-part documentary web series that travels across the country to cast a spotlight on people who are making our nation a better place, community by community. The series explores organizations and individuals that are affecting positive, tangible change in both small towns and big cities through teamwork, ingenuity, and a passion for bringing people together.

Do you ever scroll through your Twitter, Instagram, or Facebook feed, or turn on the news, hoping to read something uplifting?

A couple of years ago, Jonathan was living in Washington D.C. where the national news was also the local news. Conflict, crisis, and criticism filled the daily headlines. It got us thinking that there had to be other stories — untold stories that weren't making the headlines — of people coming together to help one another, and make their neighborhoods better places to live.

There had to be hope in our country. We decided to go look for it.

We mapped out a 5,000-mile route across 11 states from Washington, D.C., to California, and hopped in the car. From flea markets to gas stations to government buildings, in towns as big as 1,000,000 and as small as 1,000, we interviewed dozens of people. What we found were ordinary people doing extraordinary things to build up and bring together their communities:

  • High school students building homes in New Orleans
  • A chef in Santa Fe reintroducing indigenous foods to the community
  • An LGBTQ support group providing a safe space for youth in a small North Carolina town
  • Nature preservationists in Alabama partnering with a big gas company to keep their river clean 

These are just a few of the inspiring stories from our journey, and there are many more to tell.

To date, we have released 5 of our 10 episodes, and we are extremely grateful for everyone who has followed us and supported us this far!

Our goal is to complete our series, and you can make that possible. From Austin to Santa Fe to Denver and beyond, there are more stories of heroes helping to shape their neighborhoods for the better — and we need your help to share this POSITIVE news with the world. Your contribution will help us fund the post-production and release of the next 5 episodes. Our starting goal will cover our basic fees to finish these episodes (all the sexy stuff like editing, color correction, sound mixing, and licensing fees!).

Any stretch goals will help us start pre-production for Season 2, so we can continue to showcase more great people and organizations in more cities across the country. 

Money is great, but it's not the only way you can help.

Please share this campaign with your friends and family who may be interested in supporting our series.

Watch our episodes on our YouTube channel,

Follow us on social media: Twitter, Facebook, Instagram,

And find out a whole lot more on our website: www.tangiblehopeproject.org

Jonathan David Martin - Director, Executive Producer 

Jenni Fontana - Executive Producer 

Todd Ford - Producer, Creative Consultant

Austin Elston - Story Consultant 

Royd Haston - Original Music / Score

Alix Angelis - Associate Producer, Campaign Video Editor

Abby Melendrez - Fundraising Manager

Alex Lee - Graphic Design

Alligator - Honorary Team Member

Jonathan David Martin (Director, Executive Producer) is a director, producer, and actor working at the intersection of documentaries, digital technology, and live performance. Projects include Tony-award winning Broadway productions, festival-winning VR experiences, and international education and outreach initiatives.  He is the founding Co-Artistic Director of Smoke & Mirrors Collaborative (SMC), a nonprofit production company that creates original works of new media and performance around socially relevant themes. 

Jenni Fontana (Executive Producer) is an LA-based television producer and marketing executive. Her career has spanned positions in casting, production, and development, with a focus on content creation for documentary television and film projects. She has worked on series for several networks, including NBC, CNN, Netflix, and Amazon. 

Todd Ford (Producer, Creative Consultant) is a Berlin-based video and web producer. Several of his projects focus on the African Diaspora. His company is VISual EXistence.

Smoke & Mirrors Collaborative (Production Company) is a New York City-based nonprofit production company that creates original works of theater, film, and new media that give voice to unfamiliar and underrepresented stories. (Instagram/Twitter: @SmokeMirrorsCo) www.smokemirrors.org

story:
Social Emotional Learning and Representation:

  • Increasing prosocial skills to succeed in all aspects of their life. 
  • Prevents antisocial behavior leading to bullying, harassment, assault
  • Creates a social repertoire to build positive connections

Diversity and representation: The host and creator is a black ,Jewish woman. We aim to have a diverse group covering different ethnicities, genders, and disabilities. It is hard to be what you can't see, we want every child to find some of themselves in what they are viewing, to know its possible and identify.  

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking at least 15000 why?

Casting/ actors: I think it is important to pay people what they are worth. The money will go to compensating the actors in the show of which there are 5 in total including myself. 

Set up: Scenery and buying items needed for the set. We are fortunate, that I am on the board of BIG( Brookline Interactive Group) which means the physical space is free but not the set up.

Graphic Designer/Animator: In order to have the element of the white lined paper super hero, we will need to hire a graphic designer which can be costly and again compensation is important. I believe in giving people chances and paying them what they are worth. 

The Impact?

Did you know that most elementary schools are taught by women yet most children shows are hosted or centered around male leads. There is a lack of representation in children's television, specially the Kindergarten/ 1st grade age group. There is a huge market for preschool, but what about the slightly older kids who can comprehend more?

I truly believe in children. I have witnessed children working in wood shop with real tools and saying the most poignant things and they are so special and quite literally our future. In todays world parents are tired, and as someone who has worked with many different populations from low and high economic backgrounds, burn out on both sides is very real. This show is to assist in this, while giving the child security and increasing the 5 components of social intelligence. 

I believe there is a true benefit to seeing a show everyday and knowing that person will be there for you. The smaller cast as well, makes for a more intimate feel, like these people are your friends and you know and can trust them. 

As someone who has taught Autistic, severe behavioral, and multi disabilities from ages 3-19 in public, private, and charter school in two states I have a wealth of knowledge I would love to share in a fun creative way. ​

Risks & Challenges

As with any show there is always a risk that it won't be picked up however, with this show being based in Boston, we will be submitting this pilot to everywhere possible. We will start small with WGBH and move on to Hulu or Netflix. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign. If 15 thousand people each donated one dollar we would make our goal and give so many children more opportunities and support.

story:
THE STORY

 

How to L0ve is a comedic web series that follows a group of teenagers who reunite to work as ball people at their community’s local tennis tournament. The protagonists LT, Xia, and Kota are working their final tournament with the hopes of being picked for a coveted ball person job at the US Open. In the meantime, they navigate groin injuries, thirst traps, and contemporary dance choreographers. The major goal of the series is to reimagine tennis by putting black athletes at the forefront while also acknowledging famous black tennis players from the past and present. How to L0ve tells a story that is essentially queer and black in a space that has traditionally been seen as anything but.

How to L0ve is a celebration of and a collaboration between POC, the LGBT+ community, and the city of Chicago. We are excited to have assembled an entirely POC and/or femme creative team to bring the story to life. Everything from our costumes to our soundtrack is heavily influenced by Chicago, and we are collaborating with a variety of artists and organizations within the city.

We are beyond proud that How to L0ve’s creator, Robert Cunningham, was selected as a first-round recipient of Halsey’s Black Creator Funding Initiative. This support means the world to us and has helped us to lay the groundwork for the series. However, there are still costs that we need to cover.

 

 

THE TEAM

 

Robert Cunningham (he/they) is an Atlanta-born, Chicago-based actor and screenwriter. While attending Northwestern University, they starred opposite Nicolas Cage and Selma Blair in the black comedy, MOM AND DAD, and later acted in teen noir KNIVES AND SKIN. Their work focuses on queering and reclaiming predominantly white and/or heteronormative spaces through a comedic lens. 

 

Devyn Johnson is a Tennessee born, Chicago-based director and performer. After graduating from Northwestern University, she co-created Resting Witch face, an all-women’s sketch and improv comedy group, and was the AD on the Chicago web series Damaged Goods (VAM Studios). Her missions focus on facilitating spaces for minority creators to creatively challenge themselves safely, especially in comedy communities.

 

Evelyn Landow is a director of photography, editor, writer, musician and creator. Her work includes the web series “Garden Doc,” a mockumentary series co-created with her best friend; “My Teeth Shine,” a visual album of her original music and eleven music videos; and “Cautious Birth,” a documentary short chronicling the first moments discovering her trans identity. She lives in a western suburb of Chicago.

 

Jody Bailet is a Chicago-based creative producer originally from Albuquerque, New Mexico. She graduated from Northwestern University, where she studied Radio/Television/Film and Business. There, she produced a number of films and served as production chair and later president of the NU Women’s Filmmaker Alliance. Since graduating, she has worked at the Chicago International Film Festival as travel coordinator and submission screener for international feature films, and is involved in the Chicago independent production scene.


 

HOW YOUR DONATION WILL HELP

 

Paying our cast and crew - We are committed to fairly paying every single one of our cast and crew members for their hard work on this project.

Sanitation and safety measures - Our production is contingent on the health and safety of our cast and crew. We will only proceed with shooting days as long as small indoor gatherings are permitted. Additionally, we will be providing every possible on-set safety measure such as masks and sanitizing materials.

Music - We are reaching out to local Chicago artists to help us create a unique soundscape for the series. We want to ensure that all of these talented musicians are paid for their contribution to the series.

Securing locations - Shooting on professional tennis courts and locker rooms will help us to tell a story that visually challenges the preconceived notion of these spaces.

Equipment rentals - We can’t shoot a web series without gear! Your donations will help us to make our vision a reality by using the necessary camera, lights, and sound recording equipment.

On set meals - That’s right, where there are people, there must be food. We want to ensure that no one on set goes hungry or uncaffeinated!

 

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

 

We know that many of you may want to help but can’t give money at this time. If this is the case, you can still help by sharing this campaign on social media! You can also check us out on Instagram at @howtol0vewebseries
story_txt: THE STORY How to L0ve is a comedic web series that follows a group of teenagers who reunite to work as ball people at their community’s local tennis tournament. The protagonists LT, Xia, and Kota are working their final tournament with the hopes of being picked for a coveted ball person job at the US Open. In the meantime, they navigate groin injuries, thirst traps, and contemporary dance choreographers. The major goal of the series is to reimagine tennis by putting black athletes at the forefront while also acknowledging famous black tennis players from the past and present. How to L0ve tells a story that is essentially queer and black in a space that has traditionally been seen as anything but.How to L0ve is a celebration of and a collaboration between POC, the LGBT+ community, and the city of Chicago. We are excited to have assembled an entirely POC and/or femme creative team to bring the story to life. Everything from our costumes to our soundtrack is heavily influenced by Chicago, and we are collaborating with a variety of artists and organizations within the city.We are beyond proud that How to L0ve’s creator, Robert Cunningham, was selected as a first-round recipient of Halsey’s Black Creator Funding Initiative. This support means the world to us and has helped us to lay the groundwork for the series. However, there are still costs that we need to cover.  THE TEAM Robert Cunningham (he/they) is an Atlanta-born, Chicago-based actor and screenwriter. While attending Northwestern University, they starred opposite Nicolas Cage and Selma Blair in the black comedy, MOM AND DAD, and later acted in teen noir KNIVES AND SKIN. Their work focuses on queering and reclaiming predominantly white and/or heteronormative spaces through a comedic lens.  Devyn Johnson is a Tennessee born, Chicago-based director and performer. After graduating from Northwestern University, she co-created Resting Witch face, an all-women’s sketch and improv comedy group, and was the AD on the Chicago web series Damaged Goods (VAM Studios). Her missions focus on facilitating spaces for minority creators to creatively challenge themselves safely, especially in comedy communities. Evelyn Landow is a director of photography, editor, writer, musician and creator. Her work includes the web series “Garden Doc,” a mockumentary series co-created with her best friend; “My Teeth Shine,” a visual album of her original music and eleven music videos; and “Cautious Birth,” a documentary short chronicling the first moments discovering her trans identity. She lives in a western suburb of Chicago. Jody Bailet is a Chicago-based creative producer originally from Albuquerque, New Mexico. She graduated from Northwestern University, where she studied Radio/Television/Film and Business. There, she produced a number of films and served as production chair and later president of the NU Women’s Filmmaker Alliance. Since graduating, she has worked at the Chicago International Film Festival as travel coordinator and submission screener for international feature films, and is involved in the Chicago independent production scene. HOW YOUR DONATION WILL HELP Paying our cast and crew - We are committed to fairly paying every single one of our cast and crew members for their hard work on this project.Sanitation and safety measures - Our production is contingent on the health and safety of our cast and crew. We will only proceed with shooting days as long as small indoor gatherings are permitted. Additionally, we will be providing every possible on-set safety measure such as masks and sanitizing materials.Music - We are reaching out to local Chicago artists to help us create a unique soundscape for the series. We want to ensure that all of these talented musicians are paid for their contribution to the series.Securing locations - Shooting on professional tennis courts and locker rooms will help us to tell a story that visually challenges the preconceived notion of these spaces.Equipment rentals - We can’t shoot a web series without gear! Your donations will help us to make our vision a reality by using the necessary camera, lights, and sound recording equipment.On set meals - That’s right, where there are people, there must be food. We want to ensure that no one on set goes hungry or uncaffeinated!  OTHER WAYS TO HELP We know that many of you may want to help but can’t give money at this time. If this is the case, you can still help by sharing this campaign on social media! You can also check us out on Instagram at @howtol0vewebseries

story:
Midnight Coffee Productions Presents...

Hi, we're Midnight Coffee! We're a diverse team from Atlanta passionate about telling great stories with a great group of people that is passionate about filmmaking. 

We're thrilled to bring our latest project, "Dead Serious" to life! This horror-comedy follows a group of friends that find a "zombie", but it's not a zombie that everyone's familiar with in media. A wild and unworthy zombie apocalypse begins.

Filming starts in parts of Georgia this fall and it's gearing up to be a great time. But we can't do this without your help!

What we plan to do with the Donations:

For one week:

1. Paying crew (they deserve it, and we want to show it) for a week of work

2. Paying for equipment rentals, including costumes and props

3. Renting locations (we have a specific downtown location that will be so stellar for the story!)

4. Providing proper PPE and care for the safety of the crew

What we want to give to you:

Donor perks will include amazing rewards from signed merch to producer credits or even a small option to come get COVID tested for a role in the film! We really value our community, and your support is invaluable. The arts have been impacted hard during the pandemic, and we are determined to make our first project since it started the best we can.

Key Creatives:

Producer/Writer/Co-Director - Alix Oliver

Alix Oliver is a director, screenwriter, and producer.

As a young child, Alix developed an interest in pop culture, particularly in videos games, comic books and film. He loved to break down the psyche of characters to get a better feel of their purpose in the story. Although he originally wanted to pursue a career as a veterinarian, Alix soon realized that his true passion was in film making. 

In high school, Alix was struck by an SUV which caused severe neurological damage. Even though this accident had caused a major physical setback, Alix persevered to graduate Wheeler High School with honors. Promptly after graduating high school, Alix attended Kennesaw State University as well as the Georgia Film Academy. During his studies, he met several passionate film students with whom he developed friendships and, later, business relationships. 

In 2020, Alix founded "Midnight Coffee Productions," a production company which he runs with the peers he met at the Georgia Film Academy.

Producer/Co-Director - Julian Scalia

Working in the industry as an Art Director, Julian has always had a desire to tell his own stories. A Los Angeles native he has followed the great film migration to his sweet sunny southern home of Atlanta. In Atlanta, he has managed to put together a talented group of professional working filmmakers from around the country, and abroad, who share his passion to tell unique stories.

He finished his first award-winning super short film H'ilol. Shot entirely on Kodak 16mm film stock, in super 16 using only one reel of film.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Even if you can't support us financially, we would still appreciate your help! So what can you do?

Go follow us @midnightcoffeeproductions on Instagram and Facebook! We'll be sharing fun content throughout the production that you won't want to miss.

Share this campaign as far as you can! You'd be amazed how much impact a simple share on social media can have to help us reach our goal. 

Thank you for your support, and don't miss Dead Serious, coming soon!

story:
Short Summary

We are four female filmmakers who, while isolating in Brooklyn during COVID, came together over Zoom to create a comedy in the midst of our collective depression. "Ghost Town" is a comedy about dead people pursuing their dreams.  

“Ghost Town” follows small-town dead girl Jane Clay whose death hasn’t derailed her ambitions of Broadway stardom. When Trump declares New York City a "ghost town," Jane takes her death into her own hands and heads to the city where she meets a rag-tag group of ghosts who, in return for helping them with their “unfinished business” agree to act in her ghostly production of “Our Town.”

“Ghost Town” reminds us that even in our isolation, we are never truly alone.

We have seven HILARIOUS episodes, seven INCREDIBLY talented actors, and four gals who are DYING to make you laugh. 

What We Need & What You Get

We’re shooting the first three episodes in September, and your contribution will make this initial shoot possible and pave the way for subsequent shoots:

Equipment rental (it’s gonna look good!)

Audio recording and mixing (it’s gonna sound good!)

Locations, food, wardrobe and props (it ain’t cheap!)

Our creative team has cooked up some super spooky prizes for everyone who helps fund our campaign. We thank you from the bottoms of our dead little hearts.

The Impact

We are four women in a field dominated by men. Our project is proof that by supporting each other we can make a positive impact on the industry and create a strong artistic community. "Ghost Town" is a celebration of New York City and after a particularly devastating year, we want to remind the world that NYC is still a cultural epicenter and inspiration to artists. Even in the most difficult circumstances, it's never too late to band together and create something beautiful.

Risks & Challenges

Filmmaking is expensive, but we're resourceful producers.  We are lucky to be part of a vibrant artistic community who are passionate about "Ghost Town" and dedicated to making it happen.  We're calling in ALL the favors for this one. 

After writing a first season of an entirely new web series over Zoom, the shoot should be the easy part!

Other Ways You Can Help

Send this to your friends! Your moms! Your freaky second-cousins!The patrons of the arts! Get Jeff Bezos on the line!

We are so grateful for the help we've already received. For this project to succeed we're relying on a team of graphic designers, writers, actors, and filmmakers. If you are interested in being part of the "GHOST TOWN" family and/or team and want to know how else you can help, please reach out to ghosttownwebseries@gmail.com.

story:
Why I'm creating "The HOU Life" 

Houston, we DON'T have a problem. 

What we have is an ultra diverse, prosperous, and yet eccentric city and it is now time to showcase H-town's richness to the world!

We all love Houston and know it has a ton to offer, yet we often get overlooked in the national discussion about America's greatest cities. For starters, there is no media source, prominent vlog, or TV show to see the stories and the people who make Houston the 'city with no limits.'

I want to change that starting this summer.

I need your help in breathing life into this project.  Let me tell you a bit about myself and why you should contribute.

A little bit about Adeel 

I am a native New Yorker who moved to Houston in 2007 with no real plan on staying here long term.  I didn't know much about life in Texas and my friends and family up north thought I was crazy for moving to the area.

Well, I settled in with my wife, and soon we built our first home in the suburbs.  We started to meet some very friendly and helpful people and soon enough, we started to take in all the great culture that is uniquely Houston.

3 years later, we had our first child, who is a proud native Texan (and my part-time cameraman).  3 years after that our second was born here as well.  Needless to say, the Houston area is HOME and my pride for it shines through to all who know me.

 

A Quick Summary of My Professional Qualifications 

  • Professional background is 20 years in sales, PR, and marketing.  I've worked for small and large corporations and owned my own business.  I achieved national sales awards 3 times and had a great run.  But my dream is to build this brand and this show as my full-time gig. 
  • I am a board member of the Fort Bend County Citizens Engagement Group.  
  • Member of Greater Houston Partnership
  • Well connected with area leaders, business groups (TRA, Houston Lawyers Groups, Social and Activist groups).

Why am I raising funds?

To get the first season (10 episodes) off the ground, I need your help!  I have already put over $6000 of my own funds into the project; however, to produce a professional series, I need a small army of friends and well-wishers to back this project!

By contributing, you become a founding supporter and/or member of "The Hou Life."  Together we can help build up Houston and promote what is important to us all.  

To raise the remaining $10,000, I decided to turn to my community as a way for like-minded individuals to become a part of this initiative.  Your contribution - whether $3 or $500 - will help make this dream a reality.  Simply put... I can't do this without you!

With "The HOU Life," we will have a show and series that is absolutely our own.  We can highlight Houston's best businesses, sights and sounds, cultural diversity, and much more with the exposure.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding Breakdown

  • The funding ask is $10,000.  (Roughly $7800 after perks and platform fees).
  • Breakdown of how the $7,800 will be invested:
    • $ 3,500 in labor costs ($350 per episode).  This is primarily to bring on a professional videographer and editor.
    • $2,400 in promotions ($240 in digital ad spend per episode to promote it on YouTube and Facebook).
    • $1,900 in equipment costs (Additional lighting, 1 additional camera plus lens, higher-end audio).

Perks For You

  • All $50 or more contributions will get an official "Hou Life Supporter" T-Shirt plus a charging station with our logo!
  • Contributions over $100 will be part of the direction of the show and will be part of a closed Facebook group.
  • Contributions over $250 will be part of the Director's Circle and will have input into the direction of the series!

Become part of the first fully dedicated web series that highlights Houston's rich cultural heritage and modern-day diversity!  As an early contributor, you will have input into the first season.  With the highest level contributions, you will be part of my advisory team that will help select the stories, businesses, and people the series will focus on.

So What Exactly will "The Hou Life" Look Like as a Show?

"The Hou Life" will be a web series with primary broadcasts on a dedicated YouTube Channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrS7cbcf6txr_b...) as well as a Facebook Page (https://www.facebook.com/TheHouLifewithAdeelAkhtar).

  • Each episode will be 15 to 22 minutes (ideal length in today's world of shorter attention spans).
  • Each episode will focus on either
    • 1 - An interesting or prominent person with a unique story worth telling. 
    • 2 - A unique culture or Houston subculture. 
    • 3 - A unique business / food / restaurant.
    • 4 - The story of something unique to Houston (The 'Be Someone' bridge, The Astrodome, etc.)

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge to this project is competing in a space where there is already a lot of noise (Youtube / social media shows).  As barriers to entry become lower, a show like "The  HOU Life" will find itself in the middle of a endless array of choices people have to spend watching.

So what is my plan to overcome this potential hurdle?

  • Each person, business, or sight will be covered in person and on location.  People are tired of the "talking heads" split screens that have become the norm during quarantine.
  • The primary focus of the show is to elicit emotion.  I can get amazing stories told by the people who have lived them.  My strength is that I can direct the show in a way to make the audience laugh and possibly cry all within 20 minutes.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools.

And that's all there is to it.

So what is my plan to overcome this potential hurdle?

Each person, business, or sight will be covered in person and on location.  People are tired of the "talking heads" split screens that have become the norm during quarantine.
The primary focus of the show is to elicit emotion.  I can get amazing stories told by the people who have lived them.  My strength is that I can direct the show in a way to make the audience laugh and possibly cry all within 20 minutes.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

story:
Short Summary

Marching Order is a Montana-based web series produced and filmed by Montanans and featuring Montana gamers. We have a six-episode first season planned with each episode to run approximately 2 hours.

  • Creator, producer, and DM Robert Thomson has lived in Montana 18 years. While spending a career in public history with the National Park Service, US Forest Service, and Montana State Parks, he's also been a freelance roleplaying game writer, a co-owner of a small RPG publishing company, and an extra in a handful of small films.
  • This campaign will help us cover any final costs encountered as we film the episodes, the first two of which film on August 9, 2021. We have had a lot of in-kind donations for gaming products and other items to be used during the filming but could use an increased cash flow.
  • Contributors help us cover location fees, filming expenses, and crew/actor support. All contributions go back into the local community. This includes supporting local businesses and location owners. 

What We Need & What You Get

Your funding will help us complete Season 1:

  • We are fundraising for $2500.00. This  helps us cover filming costs ranging from locations, craft services, travel, props, costuming, and other general expenses.
  • To support this we are offering some great perks ranging from logo stickers, the ability to name an NPC (non-player character) the player characters will encounter, associate producer perks with IMDB credit, IMDB special thanks and other unique benefits.
  • If we don't raise the full amount, funds raised will go directly to cast/crew support.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • This production is largely funded out of pocket of our producers because we believe in what this series can become and do for the promotion of Montana-based business, actors, and crews.
  • Your generosity allows us to make Season 1 filming bigger and better, plain and simple. 

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks and challenges in a project like this. Cast/crew illnesses, travel difficulties, equipment failure, and much more can always happen. This is Montana, and trying to travel in the fall can sometimes be just as hazardous as traveling in the depths of winter.

  • All challenges will be met head-on and discussed openly with our cast and crew, and with our donors. Every effort will be made to overcome such challenges as easily and quickly as possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Helping us get the word out and making some noise about our campaign can be just as helpful as a contribution. You may help us reach a donor that would not have otherwise found us!
  • When sharing, please make sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!
